There are basically two steps to this. The first one is finding the direction of the resistors. You do this by using the current, knowing that current goes from positive to negative so path through a resistor following the current would be a voltage drop.  Then the second step is to create a loop. The loop has to start and end in the same place and result in 0. If the loop is going with the current through a resistor, then the resistor is a voltage drop, if the loop is against the current through the resistor, then the resistor is a voltage lift.   Rewatch the first 5 or so minutes to understand how the signs work.

Before understanding Kirchhoff’s Law which maybe found in several textbooks, it is useful to know how does current know how to split in parallel branches.   To answer this question one must know the role of surface charges in establishing a current and potential difference in a circuit.   Supposing there is a simple series circuit comprising a battery, wires and a resistor R1 and there is a dead-end branch with a resistor R2 across R1. When the circuit is made then initially electrons flow into both branches, but the surface of the dead-end branch becomes charged so negatively that no more electrons can enter. This prevents current flowing into the dead-end branch. Current of appropriate strength will flow in the R2 branch when the branch is connected across R1.   It is not possible in this post to discuss in more detail the rearrangement of surface charges which allows current through the branch.   Electrostatics and circuits belong to one science not two and it is instructive to understand Current, the conduction process and Voltage at the fundamental level as in the following two videos:   i. https://youtu.be/REsWdd76qxc and ii. https://youtu.be/8BQM_xw2Rfo   The last frame References in video #1 lists textbooks 3 and 4 which discuss surface charges and explains their rearrangement with the help of sequential diagrams in parallel circuits and topics on capacitive and inductive circuits using a unified approach to electrostatics and circuits.

By definition, a resistor is a sink of power, rather than a source of power.  It converts electrical energy into thermal energy.  This means that the voltage drop across it must drop in the direction that current flows, rather than rise in the direction that current flows.  Only a source of power can increase the voltage as current flows through it.  A sink of power must drop voltage, when tracing in the direction of current.

Kinda misleading tutorial. The voltage actually comes from the positive (+) sign and not the negative (-) since the negative side is just like the ground, has a zero voltage. And the current flows from low potential to high potential, aka the ground (zero) which is the negative side to the high potential (24V) which is the positive side. It doesn't matter in solving these problems but I think it matters if you really want to understand how these things work, although most schools would just use the convention (+) to (-) which is contradictory to the low-to-high potential thing.

It's kind of hard to explain but with the direction of current he chose, I1 has to go through that 4 ohm resistor because it is in series with the 20V battery and the 2 ohm resistor which each have I1 going through them. Essentially, I1 is the initial current that then flows into the parallel elements until it returns back with the same current remaining. Look back at the first example. 4 amps flow from the battery into the junction, where it splits into 3 amps and 1 amp, until it returns again with 4 amps to go back through the battery. The total current is never lost when returning to the initial position. Again, this is all relative to the direction of current that he chooses.

It is a myth that electricity takes the path of least resistance.  Electricity takes ALL POSSIBLE PATHS, inversely proportional to the resistance.  If you have a 1 kOhm resistance in parallel with a 100 Ohm resistance, you should not expect zero current in the 1 kOhm resistor.  You should expect that current will flow through both resistors, and that 10 times as much current flows through the 100 Ohm resistor in this example.

@hippityhopp4227  Voltage differences add up to zero around a closed loop, because the electric field is a conservative vector field, as long as magnetic induction does not apply.   Kirchhoff's voltage loop law is a special case of Faraday's law of induction.  The closed loop integral E dot dL = 0 (electric field dot product each infinitesimal length) for Kirchhoff, and it equals -dPHI_B/dt when magnetic induction comes in to play.  It is ultimately a manifestation of conservation of energy why this rule works.  The counterpart, Kirchhoff's current law, is a manifestation of conservation of charge.

You are allowed to decide the direction to trace voltage differences arbitrarily, as long as you keep it consistent.  You make an arbitrary guess for the direction of current flow at each location.   When you trace with the assumed direction of current, resistors subtract voltage (equal to I*R) and sources add voltage.  When you trace against the assumed direction of current, resistors add voltage (equal to I*R), and sources subtract voltage.   Voltage differences around any closed loop add up to 0 (as long as any magnetic fields are either zero or constant).   The algebra will give you the sign on each current value, to tell you if your assumed direction was correct or not.

When people talk about current flowing from positive to negative, they’re talking about “conventional current flow”. Back in the day before they knew current flows from negative to positive they wrote it backwards (positive to negative). Now this is referred to as conventional current flow and is still in use.

In our experience with the circuits we build, yes.  Since the electron is the charge carrier in most man-made circuits.  However, this isn't universally the case.  Circuits do exist where positive sodium ions are the charge carriers, like in human nerve cells.  You might also have a circuit with antimatter, or other exotic particles, where the charge carriers are positive.   Unlikely, but it could happen.  Benjamin Franklin's "mistake" that caused him to unwittingly assign the electron as negative before it was discovered, tells us to be flexible, and know that charges flow opposite the conventional current if the charges are negative.  It is q*v that sets the direction of current, rather than just v.
